original_title: Sri Lanka Treasury bosses to sign IMF pro-note
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Secretary and Deputy Secretary of the Treasury will be given permission to sign a promissory note to cover borrowings from the International Monetary Fund, Cabinet Spokesman Minister Bandula Gunawardana said.
On Monday, the IMF approved a 48-month program for Sri Lanka worth 3 billion US dollars (2.286 billion special drawing rights) or 395 percent of the Indian Ocean island’s quota.

“As per a proposal by President Ranil Wickremsinghe, after the IMF approval was given, the Secretary of the Finance Ministry or the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury will be given the permission to sign the promissory note and other official documents on behalf of Sri Lanka,” Gunawardana told reporters Tuesday.
Sri Lanka’s currency collapsed from 200 to 360 to the US dollar, as the central bank printed unprecedented volumes of money to mis-target a policy rate through 2020 and 2022.

Sri Lanka will also table IMF policy agreements, which have been made public with market sensitive data redacted, in the parliament. The Letter of Intent outlining the economic program of the government has been signed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe.
“We need to execute this plan other wise we will not be able to function,” Gunawardana said.
If any party does not agree to the program, they should come with their own solutions, he said. (Colombo/ March21/2023)
